sanskrit:
ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ।
माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः॥
transliteration:
tataḥ śvetair hayair yukte mahati syandane sthitau |
mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaś caiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ ||
translation: Then, seated in their magnificent chariot yoked with white horses, Krishna (Madhava) and Arjuna (the son of Pandu) blew their divine conches.
commentary:
This verse marks a pivotal moment as it introduces the central protagonists of the Bhagavad Gita—Krishna and Arjuna—positioned together in their chariot. The imagery is highly symbolic: the white horses represent purity and dharma, while the magnificent chariot symbolizes the body or the field of action. The blowing of divine conches is a response to Bhishma's conch blast and signals the readiness of the Pandava side for battle.

The verse specifically uses the epithet 'Madhava' for Krishna, connecting him to the goddess of fortune (Lakshmi), and emphasizes that both Krishna and Arjuna blow 'divine' (divya) conches, suggesting their transcendent nature and divine mission. This is significant because it establishes from the outset that this is not merely a worldly battle but has cosmic and spiritual dimensions. The fact that they are seated together in one chariot symbolizes the unity of the individual soul (Arjuna) with the Supreme Soul (Krishna), which becomes the central teaching of the Gita.

The positioning of this verse in the narrative creates a dramatic counterpoint to the previous descriptions of the Kaurava forces. While Duryodhana has been expressing anxiety and the Kauravas have blown their conches, now the divine duo responds, setting the stage for the spiritual discourse that will follow. The 'divine' quality of their conches foreshadows the divine knowledge that Krishna will soon impart.
speaker: Sanjaya
